raw_text:
BMW cash to fuel Mini production
 
 Less than four years after the new Mini was launched, German car maker BMW has announced £100m of new investment.
 
 Some 200 new jobs are to be created at the Oxford factory, including modernised machinery and a new body shell production building. The result of the investment could be to raise output to more than 200,000 cars from 2007. The rise, from 189,000 last year, is a response to rapidly-rising demand and could help wipe out waiting lists. Before Wednesday's announcement, BMW had invested some £280m in Mini production.
 
 Since its launch during summer 2001, the new Mini has gone from strength to strength.
 
 Last year, almost one in six cars sold by the BMW group was a Mini. The company admits that the success of the brand came despite scepticism from many in the industry. "Our decision to produce a new Mini was not received well right away," said Norbert Reithofer, a member of the BMW management board. Initially, BMW said it would produce 100,000 Mini models a year at its vast Cowley factory on the outskirts of Oxford, but the target was quickly reached, then raised, time and time again. Not everyone is convinced that the boom can continue. "The risk is that after they've invested massively in the brand, demand tapers off like it did with the new VW Beetle," said Brad Wernle, from Automotive News Europe.
 
 The price of the car has also gone up. When it was launched, the cheapest Mini cost just more than £10,000. These days, buyers will have to fork out almost £11,500 to own a new Mini One, or even more for the Cooper S which costs up to £17,730. The Mini Convertible, which was launched last spring, costs up to £15,690 for the top model, and there is even a waiting list. Second-hand Minis are not cheap either. A Mini One bought when the model was launched should still fetch at least £8,000 for the cheapest model, while a used Cooper S is likely to be priced from £12,556, according to the-car buying website Parker's. The consumers' association Which operates with slightly different numbers, yet it confirms that the Mini Cooper 1.6 depreciates slower than any other car, other than the Mercedes Benz C180 SE and the BMW 1 Series 116i SE.
 
 The Cowley factory, which initially seemed far too large a production plant for just 100,000 Minis, is increasingly being put to good use.
 
 There are plans to tear down old buildings and build new ones and there are rumours that a new paint shop could be included in the plans. BMW's Mini adventure has made good much of what went wrong during its stewardship of the UK car maker Rover which it sold for £10 five years ago to the Phoenix consortium. In 1999, when BMW still owned Rover, the Oxford factory was producing the award-winning Rover 75. During that year, 3,500 people produced 56,000 cars. Last year, in the same factory, almost four times as many vehicles were produced by just 4,500 Mini-workers. The Mini factory's current output is equally impressive when compared with the main Rover factory in Longbridge, which in 1999 produced 180,000 Rover cars. Last year, MG Rover, which employs more than 6,000 people, produced just 110,000 cars, though it hopes to land a deal with Shanghai Automotive Industry Corporation (SAIC) that could help double the number of cars produced at Longbridge. Indeed, Mini is not only producing more cars than MG Rover does; it remains ahead even when the current sales of Land Rovers and Range Rovers (which are made by the former Rover unit that BMW sold to Ford) are taken into account.
llama3.2:1b: BMW has announced £100m in new investment for its Oxford factory, creating 200 new jobs and increasing production capacity to potentially reach over 200,000 cars per year.
The investment could help meet rising demand, which has led to a significant increase in car sales from just 189,000 last year to almost one in six.

BMW initially planned for 100,000 models per year but reached that target quickly, and now aims to produce more as the brand's popularity continues to grow despite skepticism from some industry experts.
The company is investing in modern machinery and a new body shell production building at its Cowley factory, which has become increasingly busy with demand.
The investment could help increase output by up to 200,000 cars per year, potentially wiping out waiting lists.
llama3.2:3b: BMW is investing £100m in its Oxford factory to modernize machinery and create 200 new jobs, aiming to produce over 200,000 cars per year.
The investment follows rising demand for Mini cars, which has created waiting lists.
Despite initial skepticism from the industry, the brand's success has been significant, with Mini accounting for almost one in six BMW car sales last year.
gemma2:2b: BMW is investing £100 million in its Mini production facility, creating 200 new jobs.
This investment will modernize machinery and boost output to over 200,000 cars annually.
The Mini's success has surprised many, with sales exceeding expectations despite skepticism from some industry experts.
Despite rising prices, demand for the Mini remains strong, leading to a waiting list.
The Cowley factory is now producing more vehicles than it ever did during its time making Rover cars.
qwen2.5:0.5b:
Here's a summary of the key points in brief:

- BMW announced £100m investment for its Mini production.
- Some 200 new jobs will be created at Oxford factory, including modernized machinery and new building.
- The rise from 189,000 cars to over 200,000 is not well-received by many in the industry.
- BMW had invested £280m in Mini production but plans to expand beyond its initial target.
- Prices of Mini models have increased.
For example, a 165th model costs up to £7,930 for the Cooper S.
qwen2.5:1.5b: BMW announces £100m investment in Mini production, creating 200 jobs at an Oxford factory, aiming to boost output from 189,000 to over 200,000 cars by 2007.
Price increase due to demand surge and brand success despite industry skepticism.
BMW also plans for new paint shop in Cowley factory, which was initially seen as too large but is now being put to good use with increased production of Mini vehicles.
The company has recently surpassed Rover production in the UK and outproduces MG Rover and Land Rovers/Range Rovers in terms of car output.
qwen2.5:3b: BMW has announced £100m investment in the Oxford Mini production, aiming to boost output from 189,000 last year to over 200,000 by raising demand through modern machinery and a new body shell building.
The move comes after initial production of 100,000 annually grew to over 400,000.
Despite BMW's original scepticism about the brand's success, the Mini now accounts for nearly one-sixth of the BMW group’s sales.
However, this rise in demand has also led to price increases and a growing waiting list.
The Cowley factory, initially seen as too large for such production numbers, is increasingly productive with plans for new buildings and potential new paint shops.
Mini's success contrasts sharply with Rover, which BMW sold for £10 million five years ago, highlighting the different performance of its former UK car manufacturing subsidiary.

Increasing demand can wipe out waiting lists in the industry.
The rise from 189,000 last year is a response to the current demand and could help in boosting output.
The price of the car also has gone up with prices as high as £11,500 for the cheapest model, which is expected in a new Mini One.
The Mini Convertible can be priced as low as £15,690 for the top model.
Second-hand Minis are not cheap either.
The Mini Cooper 1.6 depreciates slower than any other car, with prices ranging from £8,000 to £17,730 for the cheapest model.
smollm:1.7b:
The summary should be:

BMW has announced £100m of new investment in its Mini production, which could help fuel the UK's car market and wipe out waiting lists.
The rise from 189,000 last year to 2007 is a response to rapidly-rising demand and could help BMW's Mini become one of the best-selling cars on the roads in Europe.
The new investment will be used to modernise the Oxford factory, which was previously used to produce the award-winning Rover 75.
The factory is expected to increase its output by at least three times over the next two years, helping to meet growing demand for Mini cars from consumers and other car manufacturers.
deepseek-r1:1.5b: BMW announced a £100 million investment in Mini production after its launch, which was supported by 200 new jobs at the Oxford factory.
This investment could boost output to over 200k cars from last year's 189k.
The price of Mini has risen, with Cooper S models now costing up to £17,730 and a waiting list available for second-hand cars starting at £8k.
Before the announcement, BMW had invested £280m in Mini production.
The factory is increasingly used more efficiently, with plans to reorganize and tear down old buildings while building new ones.
BMW sold Rover (used) to the Phoenix consortium in 1999, which produced 56k cars with 3,500 workers.
In contrast, Mini produced 4.5k workers at Longbridge, producing 180k cars last year.
Despite being behind Rover in their segment, Mini remains a strong competitive player due to rising demand and improved pricing compared to other models.
tinyllama:1.1b: BMW has announced a £100m investment in Mini production, boosting output from 200,000 units last year to almost 250,000 in 2020.
The company's decision to produce the new Mini instead of Mercedes-Benz C-Class and BMW 1 Series has helped improve demand for the brand, with more than one million cars sold in the UK so far.
The launch of the new Minis' success came despite criticism from some industry professionals who said it was a risky decision.
Despite facing challenges like rising demand, the success of the brand is not being affected by the investment.

As reported by automotive news outlet Automotive News Europe, the latest figures show the 250,000 target for 2020 has been exceeded, with the projected output from Cowley Factory in Oxford surpassing one million units produced to date.
Despite the growth of Minis, there are plans to expand and create new buildings at the factory to improve efficiency further.

In addition to its new investment, BMW's Mini Adventure has made good much of what went wrong during its stewardship of Rovers, with 3,500 people producing 56,000 cars at the Oxford factory in just five years.
The factory is expected to produce around 120,000 units in 2020.
tinydolphin:1.1b: The Oxford factory has made a significant investment in the production of the Mini, with German car maker BMW committing £100 million to modernize machinery and build new body shells.
This decision comes after recent claims that demand for Mini cars had faltered amidst competition from larger brands like Volkswagen Group's VW Beetle.
The investment also comes as the brand has experienced success with its new model, which features a fresh design and improved engine options.
The Oxford factory will continue to produce the Mini One, as well as its more expensive counterparts, such as the Cooper S and the John Cooper Works.
In addition to this, BMW plans to develop a new paint shop at the Cowley factory, which is slated for completion by 2015.
This investment in the UK car manufacturing industry is part of a broader strategy within the German corporation's parent company, the Bavarian Motor Union (BMW).
The BMW Group has long been associated with innovative technology and design, making it a natural fit for the Mini brand to expand its production capabilities.

Despite initial skepticism and high prices, demand for Minis has been consistently strong, with the car losing only 3% of its value after two years compared to other popular models like the Mercedes-Benz C180 SE and BMW 1 Series  116i SE.
